section.title: Overview
section.para: TorqueBox includes a support package which includes Rake tasks which assist in the deployment to and undeployment from an instance of the TorqueBox Server, in addition to the launching of the server. This rake-based support is normally intended for development-time usage, and not for production. More advanced tooling, such as Capistrano (see Capistrano Support) is advisable for production environments.
First, the $TORQUEBOX_HOME and $JBOSS_HOME variables must be set to the path of the top of your TorqueBox Installation and the JBoss installation inside of it, respectively, as described in .
To include these tasks into your Rakefile, use a single require statement.
Once these variables are set and you have adjusted your Rakefile, you may perform directory- or archive-based deployments and control the execution of the TorqueBox AS.

section.title: Directory-based deployments
section.para: The typical usage of the rake tasks is to perform a deployment of your current application into a local TorqueBox AS during development. The simplest deployment form will deploy the application with RACK_ENV or RAILS_ENV set to development, no virtual host, at the root of the server.
If you wish to deploy with a different value for RACK_ENV or RAIL_ENV, the task respects your current shell's values for those variables.

You may supply a name argument, either as a rake parameter or as an environment variable, to adjust the name of your -knob.yml file. If not supplied, the name of the deployment defaults to the current directory name.
For example, running "rake torquebox:deploy NAME=foo" will create a deployment artifact called "foo-knob.yml" and deploy it accordingly.
Additionally, a custom context path may be used instead of the default to of /, by providing a rake argument to the torquebox:deploy task.

section.title: Archive-based deployments
section.para: In the event you need to deploy the application as an archive, instead of as a directory of loose files, the rake support includes a task to do just that. section.title: Server control
section.para: You may also control the server using the torquebox:run rake task.
The server will retain control of the console while it is running. To stop the server, simply send a SIGINT, typically using by typing control-C.
